title: Sold Out of Africa
storyIntro: Lucy is captured and taken away from all that is safe and familiar.
historyIntro: Millions of captured Africans imprisoned at the West Africa coast were sold and forced into the ships that would transport them to the Americas in the infamous Middle Passage.

title: For Sale Again
storyIntro: Three-year old Lucy is among a group of captured Africans for sale in Bristol, Rhode Island.
historyIntro: Africans who survived capture and the horrors of the Middle Passage encountered a world where loss of freedom and the arbitrary power of their enslavers were the only constants.

title: A Strange New Life
storyIntro: Eight-year-old Lucy arrives in a new place but her status as an enslaved child does not change.
historyIntro: Enslaved people could be sold at a moment’s notice to new captors anytime, anywhere, upending any and all relationships including parents, children, siblings and spouses.

title: Enslaved at the Wells's House
storyIntro: Lucy and Cesar are expected to undertake the most menial tasks on a rural farm in an unending cycle of labor.
historyIntro: Enslaved people provided essential, often backbreaking agricultural labor but unlike free members of an 18th-century household, they worked for someone else’s benefit.

frames.storyText: In colonial New England, work days for enslaved people began long before daybreak — long before their enslavers got up to begin their own work days.

While Ebenezer and Abigail Wells continue to sleep in their comfortable bed downstairs, Lucy arises from her straw-filled mattress in the garret and lights a candle so that she can see to dress for the day.

moreHowLinks.title: Floor Plans of the Wells House

frames.storyText: Cesar, sleeping on another garret mattress, also awakens and dresses. Lucy and Cesar slip quietly down the stairs to the kitchen.
There, Cesar builds a new fire on the embers remaining from the night before, while Lucy begins to prepare breakfast for the Wells. She and Cesar will eat later.

title: Joining the Church
storyIntro: Lucy joins a baptized body of Protestant believers, free and enslaved, who believe they have experienced God’s saving grace.
historyIntro: Enslaved people who embraced Christianity were still expected to accept what enslavers insisted was their God-ordained station in this life: human property.

title: Singer of History
storyIntro: Lucy sings her poem, the Bars Fight, to customers in Ebenezer Wells’s tavern.
historyIntro: Many enslaved people brought their story-telling and oral traditions to the Americas. Their talent could sometimes confer social status in the White community.

title: In the Community
storyIntro: Running errands for her enslaver, Lucy stops at the busy Williams store, encountering many people including one who might play a central role in her life.
historyIntro: New Englanders at times permitted enslaved people to earn a bit of money; their purchases of rum, tobacco, chocolate, and textiles linked them to the trans-Atlantic slave economy.

title: Community Within Community
storyIntro: As Abijah walks Lucy home along the village street they encounter several Black residents of Deerfield and surrounding towns.
historyIntro: An interior network of relationships among enslaved and free people of color fostered an essential “community within community” in Deerfield and other New England towns.

frames.storyText: “Walk you home?” “Yes, please,” replies Lucy. "I bought a little chocolate — do you like sipping chocolate? I don't often buy such a treat.” Lucy wonders if Mrs. Wells would allow her to invite Abijah to the house. Wouldn’t it be nice to have a home of one’s own…and to be able to see who you please, whenever you please...?
frames.moreBlurb: Store account books provide rich and fascinating evidence of people's participation in the 18th century economy.

moreTopicLinks.title: Stimulating Beverages and the Slave Economy

moreHowLinks.title: Account Book Record of Chocolate Purchase

frames.storyText: Lucy wonders, "Is this a courtship? Is Abijah thinking of marriage?" He is free, she is not. Marrying isn't possible if the Wells won’t allow it. Even if her enslavers agree, would Abijah want to marry a woman whose children will be born into slavery? She doesn't want that for her children.
frames.moreBlurb: Enslaved people were reminded of their limited autonomy on a daily basis.

moreHowLinks.title: Newspaper Ad for the Sale of a Woman and Children

frames.storyText: Lucy's thoughts are interrupted by some nearby children: “Lucy, you promised us a story!” “I'll sing for you later!" “Tell them your Bars Fight” Abijah suggests, while he thinks to himself, "Lucy seems to know everyone in town."
frames.alt: 2  lucy and abijah small on main street, kids enter
frames.moreBlurb: Many enslaved people played an active role in the wider community.

moreHowLinks.title: Colonial Boy's Clothing: "Portrait of Two Boys"

frames.alt: 3 Lucy and abijah medium on main, horse enters
frames.moreBlurb: A rigid social hierarchy defined the role and status of every member of the community in the 18th century.

frames.storyText: “I think I see Heber and Adam Honestman coming this way. When did Adam get so tall?”
frames.moreBlurb: An interior, “community within community” reflected efforts by people of color, free and enslaved, to maintaining a social life and emotional connections with one another, despite often overwhelming odds.

frames.storyText: The Honestmans have come to town to shop at Captain Williams’s store. Lucy asks Heber if his foot still pains him. “Sometimes,” he replies, “but I wonder what a bear would think to see me caught in one of my own traps!” Lucy thinks about another Black man who needs a crutch: Pompey’s feet froze like blocks of ice after Joseph Barnard made him cut and sled wood every day one bitter winter.
frames.moreBlurb: The coercion that was part of daily life for enslaved people could also include physical and emotional abuse.

moreHowLinks.title: Heber Honestman's account at Elijah Williams' store
Ox Cart:  "Horned Cattle Drawing a Dung Cart"

frames.storyText: Talk turns to the possible war that is on everyone's mind. "I'm thinking of joining up again, the pay is good and we need to protect our towns if there's a war." Lucy shudders to think of Abijah in battle. Watching, Heber concludes his Susanna is right: Abijah Prince is surely courting Lucy.
frames.moreBlurb: Enlisting in the militia during wartime offered the possibility of freedom for some enslaved men, but military service could be perilous and uncertain.

moreTopicLinks.title: Western Massachusetts in the French and Indian War

frames.storyText: Heber turns to Adam. “Son, it is time to get on with our errands.” Adam nods and cracks his whip. Over the creaking of cart wheels Abijah says, “You have a fine son, Heber. God willing, one day I will have a lad such as Adam.”
frames.moreBlurb: Men and women in 18th-century New England hoped to marry and raise a family in an independent household—a goal that enslaved people could not hope to attain.

frames.storyText: “Heber and Susanna have a good farm, like the place I’ll be getting now that I’ve bought my freedom,” says Abijah, hinting at a possible future with Lucy. Worried that he has been too forward, he shifts to the weather. Lucy smiles and nods but wishes Abijah would talk more about his future. She hopes she's right that his plans include her...but how can that possibly happen?
frames.moreBlurb: At a time when most people were farmers, owning land was the typical path to independence and prosperity—a goal that often proved elusive, especially for people of color.

frames.storyText: Abijah and Lucy greet Jin Cole. "Good day! Mr. Ashley is writing his Sunday sermons and had me take the children along so they will not disturb him. He's hired out Cato to work for Samuel Dickinson today, so I‘m bringing him his nooning meal."
frames.moreBlurb: Enslavers and non-enslavers alike bought and sold enslaved labor in a social and economic web that defined the community.

frames.storyText: As Abijah and Lucy walk away, Jin thinks, “What a handsome couple. Abijah has had to wait a long time to marry.” She believes Abijah has the will and the means to buy Lucy’s freedom from the Wells. Thinking about her own situation, Jin has little hope that her enslavers will free her or her son.
frames.moreBlurb: Marriage to a man who wished to and could afford to purchase her was one path to freedom for an enslaved woman.

frames.storyText: Lucy knows that Jin has always had to care for the Ashley children even as she raised Cato on her own. She remembers when Jin first arrived in Deerfield with Cato as a baby in her arms. Lucy hopes to have more for herself and any children God may send to her ... and Abijah.
frames.moreBlurb: Under the law, any child born to an enslaved mother was automatically enslaved from birth.

frames.storyText: Having finally arrived at the Wells house, Lucy does not want her visit with Abijah to end. Should she invite him in? What would Mrs. Wells think? Would she allow it? Lucy wouldn’t have to worry about such things if she and Abijah had a home of their own.
frames.moreBlurb: Their lack of autonomy affected enslaved people constantly and in many ways, large and small.

frames.storyText: As he watches Lucy pass through the door, Abijah comes to a decision. He will share his intentions with Ebenezer Wells and ask him for permission to marry Lucy.
frames.moreBlurb: Colonial New Englanders, free and enslaved, lived in a patriarchal and hierarchical society in which the heads of their households decided who could or should marry.

title: A Fruitful Union
storyIntro: Lucy and Abijah get married and begin their life together as free people.
historyIntro: If an enslaved women was emancipated, her new status ensured that any children she might have would be born free.

title: Sons of the Revolution
storyIntro: Like many Black mothers, Lucy sends her sons off to fight in the Revolution.
historyIntro: Even as they embraced the promises of the American Revolution, African American and Indigenous people knew the bitter irony of fighting for freedom alongside colonial enslavers.

title: Hostile Neighbors
storyIntro: Lucy and Abijah face intimidation and violence from hostile neighbors as they struggle to make a life for themselves on their Vermont farm.
historyIntro: Even as Vermont’s constitution put slavery on the defensive, free African Americans often encountered challenges as they endeavored to live and prosper as citizens of a new nation.

title: Fighting for Justice
storyIntro: Lucy fights in court to protect her family's legal claim to their land and for fair treatment by their neighbors.
historyIntro: The laws of Vermont and other New England states protected their citizens’ property rights while simultaneously posing challenges to those rights for free people of color.

title: Returning to Deerfield
storyIntro: Her children are grown and Lucy is recently widowed when she decides to return to Deerfield for a visit.
historyIntro: Continued ties between formerly enslaved people with families and communities where they were enslaved highlight a sense of connection to people and place, both positive and negative.
